Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in Japan
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Peter Joseph Hundt of the University of Minnesota to conduct a research project, entitled "Assessing diet of a nearshore marine fish (Teleostei: Blenniidae) from two ecosystems in Japan," during the summer of 2012 at Kochi University in Kochi, Japan. The host scientists are Dr. Kosaku Yamaoka and Dr. Yohei Nakamura.

The Intellectual Merit of the research project is furthering knowledge of what organisms eat, how they obtain it, and implications on evolutionary history. An excellent group to study the evolution of these interactions is the perciform family Blenniidae. This group of diminutive near-shore marine fishes exhibits the widest array of oral tooth and jaw morphologies in any group of perciform fishes; including teeth that widely vary in shape, number, and mode of attachment and replacement and a lower jaw that has an extra articulation. The diet of many blennies is poorly known, yet is important for understanding the evolution of trophic specialization. This research on the diet study of blennies (Teleostei: Blenniidae) from two different ecosystems in Japan promises to provide the following: 1) the first description of diet for some blenny species, 2) additional information on some previously studied species, and 3) a test of hypotheses using diet in conjunction with morphological and molecular data about evolution and correlation of the diet and feeding morphologies of blennies.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this study was to describe and investigate the diet of a family (Blenniidae) common, near shore marine fishes. Blennies (Family Blenniidae) are found throughout the world’s tropical and warm temperature marine waters. They are of interest to biologists because they exhibit the widest array of oral tooth and jaw morphologies in almost any group of fishes. This includes teeth that widely vary in shape, number, and mode of attachment and replacement, and a lower jaw that has an extra articulation. These feeding morphologies are often highly correlated with diet and may have played an important role in the evolutionary history of blennies. In order to study the correlation of diet and feeding morphologies or structures, diet data must be available. Unfortunately, the diet of many blennies is poorly known.

Blenny specimens, representing thirty species, were collected using hand nets, aided by SCUBA and/or snorkel, in Kochi and Okinawa-jima, Japan. These prefectures were selected to facilitate comparison of diet of blennies from different climate zones: Kochi is warm temperate while Okinawa is subtropical. Preserved blennies were dissected in a laboratory at Kochi University and stomach contents were identified with the aid of a light microscope. Diet data were organized by climate type and further categorized into habitat zones (subtidal, intertidal, and supralittoral).  An analysis was conducted that clustered similar blenny diets into feeding groups, which provides insight into which species have similar diets. A second analysis was used to investigate potential diet differences of species within and among habitat and climate zones.

This study provides a detailed description of the diet of thirty blenny species from Japan. Many different food items were found in the stomach contents of blennies, including fish scales, coral polyps, water mites, algae, and detritus. The cluster analysis grouped blennies of Japan into seven distinct trophic guilds, covering a wide range of specialist (e.g. fish scale eaters) and generalist (e.g. omnivores) diets. Blennies living in different climate zones and habitat zones appear to have different diets while there appears to be no difference between the diets of blennies from a specific between climate zones. The diet data collected in this study are a crucial component of a larger study, which aims to investigate the evolution of feeding morphologies and structures of blennies.


Last Modified: 11/30/2012
Modified by: Peter J Hundt
